title: Live updates: Israel launches ‘preemptive strike’ on Iran’s nuclear program
description: Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz said Israel had launched a “preemptive strike” against Iran and declared a “special emergency situation” in case of retaliation.
author: Lior Soroka, Rachel Pannett
byline: Lior Soroka, Rachel Pannett, Janice Kai Chen, Yeganeh Torbati, Washington Post staff, Shira Rubin, Matt Viser, Alex Horton
excerpt: Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz said Israel had launched a “preemptive strike” against Iran and declared a “special emergency situation” in case of retaliation.
text: Israel launched what it said was a “preemptive strike” on Iran’s nuclear program and other military targets early Friday local time. In a televised address, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the goal of the operation was “to damage Iran’s nuclear infrastructure, its ballistic missile factories and military capabilities.”  Live coverage contributors 8Return to menuMahtab, a woman in northern Tehran, said she saw the sky turn red early Friday before she heard the sound of explosions. It could be a year. html:
Israel launched what it said was a “preemptive strike” on Iran’s nuclear program and other military targets early Friday local time. In a televised address, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the goal of the operation was “to damage Iran’s nuclear infrastructure, its ballistic missile factories and military capabilities.”  

Live coverage contributors 8

  • Return to menu

    Mahtab, a woman in northern Tehran, said she saw the sky turn red early Friday before she heard the sound of explosions. The windows of her home shook. She could hear planes flying overhead and the sirens of emergency vehicles blaring.

  • Return to menu

    Israelis gather in a shelter following sirens in Tel Aviv early Friday.

  • Return to menu

    “This operation will continue for as many days as it takes to remove this threat,” Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said early Friday in a video statement published in Hebrew and English. “This is a clear and present danger to Israel’s very survival,” he said, adding that Iran could “produce a nuclear weapon in a very short time. It could be a year. It could be a few months.”

  • Rubio says U.S. forces not involved in Iran strikes, warns Iran not to target U.S.

    Return to menu

    Secretary of State Marco Rubio, in a statement distributed by the White House, confirmed the Israeli attacks against Iran but made clear that there is no involvement by the United States.

    “We are not involved in strikes against Iran and our top priority is protecting American forces in the region,” he said. “Israel advised us that they believe this action was necessary for its self-defense.”

  • Return to menu

    There was no U.S. involvement or assistance in the strikes, according to a U.S. official who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the ongoing operation. It was not immediately clear whether the United States would participate in defensive strikes such as shooting down Iranian drones or missiles. “That’s up to the president,” the official said.
